annotation.TEXT: This saying is often attributed to James Dean, Jim Morrison, or another person who did, in fact, die young. It’s actually a line from the 1949 film Knock on Any Door, spoken by actor John Derek.
The Lionel Corporation was a manufacturer of toy trains from 1900-95, founded by Joshua Lionel Cowen.
“Beer Barrel Polka” is one of Wisconsin’s unofficial state songs; it is played at assorted University of Wisconsin games as well as Green Bay Packers home games.
“Scarface” was the nickname given to mobster Al Capone; it’s also the title of a 1983 Al Pacino mobster movie.
A 2011 study hypothesized that the shape of the ear canal causes certain frequencies to resonate painfully, which is what makes that sound so godawful annoying.
A huge, complex scandal during the Reagan administration that involved selling illegal arms to Iran in order to free hostages and secretly fund Contra rebels in Nicaragua.
“We the People” is the phrase that opens the Preamble to the US Constitution. It was written by Gouverneur Morris, a delegate from Pennsylvania.
A line from the David Bowie song “Space Oddity.”
Party line phone systems are a setup (formerly common in rural areas) in which multiple customers share the same line. Members sometimes enjoyed listening in on each other’s conversations.
This is how Larry introduced his two silent brothers, Darryl and Darryl, on the ‘80s TV sitcom Newhart.
Although the fizzing effect of Pop Rocks is perfectly safe, rumors quickly spread on playgrounds across the nation that eating them while drinking soda would cause your stomach to explode.
The opening line to the classic Aretha Franklin R&B song “Chain of Fools,” released in 1967.
The Robot vs. the Aztec Mummy: Fully annotated by The Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
A paraphrased version of the song “Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Ole Oak Tree,” a #1 hit for Dawn featuring Tony Orlando (no, not the other way around) in 1973.
Floyd Lawson was Mayberry’s barber on the TV sitcom The Andy Griffith Show from 1961-67.
The Betty Crocker Kitchens, located in General Mills HQ in Golden Valley, Minnesota, are world famous.
Tyco Toys, founded by John Tyler in 1926, made many playthings, including model railroad kits. The name is a contraction of “Tyler Company.”
An imitation of Joe Ross, who played Officer Gunther Toody on Car 54, Where Are You? His partner was Officer Francis Muldoon (played by Fred Gwynne).
Robert Bork, known for his unusual goatee as well as his hard-right legal opinions, was unsuccessfully nominated for the Supreme Court by Ronald Reagan.
Opie Taylor was the son of Sheriff Andy Taylor on The Andy Griffith Show. He was played by Ron Howard.
“Imitation is the sincerest of flattery” is an aphorism written by Charles Caleb Colton, a 19th-century English cleric.
The US govt founded Radio Free Europe in 1949 to undermine communist regimes in Eastern Europe by poisoning the minds of their citizens with thoughts of freedom and rock & roll.
Abra Cadaver is the Frankenstein’s monster character in the comic strip “The Wizard of Id.”
Born Ernest Jennings Ford, Tennessee Ernie Ford was a singer and TV host. His biggest hit was “Sixteen Tons,” released in 1955.
The pushmi-pullyu is an animal from the Dr. Dolittle children’s books: an antelope with a head on either end of its body and a tendency to try to walk in two directions at once.
Teleflora is a flower wire delivery service (like FTD or 1-800-FLOWERS) that sends orders for flower arrangements around the world. It was established in the ‘30s.
Juan Valdez is the longtime ad icon for Colombian coffee growers, usually shown in the fields with his trusty mule. He first appeared in 1959.
Beaver returned in the TV movie sequel Still the Beaver in 1983 and on the series that followed, The New Leave It to Beaver, which ran from 1985-89.
“How low can you go?” is a line from the song “Limbo Rock,” first recorded by The Champs but popularized by Chubby Checker’s 1962 cover.
During WWII, in addition to selling “defense bonds” to finance the war through the banks, the government set up a payroll deduction scheme at many companies to sell bonds to employees.
Charles Pack organized the US victory garden campaign in 1917, encouraging civilians to grow their own fruits and vegetables during WWI to increase the nation’s food supply.
The concept of “women and children first” during disasters at sea was popularized by the Titanic. In fact, men tend to have an overall survival rate of 34%, compared to 17% for women.
The phrase, “Meanwhile, back at _____,” originated with cards inserted in silent films of the early 20th century. In westerns, it was often “Meanwhile, back at the ranch ...”
Traditionally, losing players on game shows receive “lovely parting gifts,” usually merchandise donated by the show’s sponsors in exchange for an on-air plug.
On Arrested Development, Ron “Opie” Howard stated that he calls all his barbers Floyd.
“Who’s buried in Grant’s tomb?” was a recurring question on the Groucho Marx quiz show You Bet Your Life, although it predates the show. Grant and his wife Julia are both entombed aboveground.
Women’s mag Cosmopolitan is known for its quizzes on various subjects, but especially sexytimes. One sample: “Which Samantha Jones Sex Scene Are You?”
The film Dirty Dancing starred Jennifer Grey as a teen who falls in love with a dance instructor (Patrick Swayze) while on vacation in the Catskills.
With annotations provided by The Annotated MST website.
After the 9/11 attacks, “Walk Like an Egyptian” was on the list of songs Clear Channel asked its radio stations not to play.
A paraphrase of a line from Stanley Kubrick’s classic film Dr. Strangelove, spoken by General Buck Turgidson (George C. Scott).
Actress Kitty Carlisle was best known as a regular panelist on To Tell the Truth, a game show in which the celebrity panel must decide which of three contestants is associated with a story.
Floyd the Barber has had an oddly substantive impact on pop culture. Nirvana has a song called “Floyd the Barber.”
Dracula, invented by a British Victorian, was fended off by a cross. Richard Matheson’s I Am Legend, written in 1954, had Jewish vampires fear a Star of David instead.
A line from the theme song to the ‘60s animated series Milton the Monster, about a mad scientist and his sweet-natured creation.
“Snuggie” here does not refer to the cozy sleeved blankets, but is an alternate term for a wedgie.
The TV show Sons of Anarchy had a town barber named Floyd (played by James Carraway).
From the ‘70s-‘90s, Jell-O made a dessert called Jell-O 1-2-3, which separated into three strata as it cooled: a creamy, custard-style layer; a normal Jell-O layer; and an odd foamy layer.
Dr. Pepper was first introduced in 1885 by a pharmacist in Waco, Texas.
Legendary fashion designer Coco Chanel famously embraced trousers for women, and her “Chanel suit” is still a classic, but the two don’t go together: her suit consists of a jacket and skirt combo.
Lipton made large glass containers specifically for brewing sun tea, but now this practice is discouraged, as it can lead to the growth of harmful bacteria in the tea.
“Me and My Shadow” is a 1927 song credited to Billy Rose, Dave Dreyer, and Al Jolson, though many believe that Jolson, who performed the song, was listed only so he could earn royalties.
A line from the song “I Feel Pretty” from the musical West Side Story.
Ads in the ‘70s had a boy asking an owl how many licks it took to get to the center of a Tootsie Pop (answer: 3; then it becomes so delicious you can’t stand it anymore and just start chewing).
A purie (or clearie) is a clear colored glass marble.
Brought to you by the Official MST3K YouTube Channel.
19th-century microbiologist Louis Pasteur created “pasteurization,” by which a food or liquid is heated and then cooled rapidly, killing most harmful bacteria and helping it stay fresh longer.
This riff was apparently something Josh Weinstein said to make Joel laugh, so they kept using it.
After splitting with Lewis, Dean Martin had a very successful career as one of The Rat Pack and hosted a hit variety show on TV.
In the Star Trek episode “The City on the Edge of Forever,” a storefront with a window reading “Floyd’s Barber Shop” was visible because it was filmed on the Andy Griffith Show backlot.
In 1874, “Tom Collins” was a prank: the victim would be told this Collins fellow had been insulting him and go in search of vengeance. Two years later “Tom Collins” had a drink named after him.
Tootsie Pops are lollipops filled with their signature chocolate chews, first created in 1931.
Krups is a German appliance maker founded in 1846.
James Arness is Peter Graves’s brother. He is best known for playing Marshal Matt Dillon on Gunsmoke.
A paraphrase of astronaut Neil Armstrong’s first words as he walked on the Moon on July 20, 1969.
A paraphrase of the song “My Blue Heaven,” originally recorded by Gene Austin: “Molly and me and the baby makes three.”
A paraphrase of the introduction to the TV series Dragnet, spoken by Jack Webb in his role as Sgt. Joe Friday.
In the playground game of marbles, a cat’s eye is a clear marble with a colored injection resembling the slit of a cat’s pupil.
In early episodes of the ‘70s police drama Kojak, the title character smoked, but producers decided to give him Tootsie Pops as a substitute, which became a trademark.
In his first appearance, Floyd was portrayed by Walter Baldwin. In every subsequent episode, he was played by Howard McNear.
The first regular TV show to be closed captioned for the hearing impaired was a 1972 episode of The Mod Squad.
McNear was a superb detective, however, on the radio show Speed Gibson of the International Secret Police, where he played Speed’s uncle, Clint Barlow.
Throughout the run of the show, McNear’s health worsened; he had a serious stroke in season 3 that limited his mobility.
“Peas and carrots” is one of those phrases that background extras mutter to simulate conversation in TV shows and films.
The Republic Pictures movie studio was known primarily for producing hundreds of serials, though they did release several classic films, including Sands of Iwo Jima and The Quiet Man.
A jingle from a series of Mazola corn oil ads in the ‘70s.
Probably the most famous Chanel suit in history is the pink one Jackie Kennedy wore in Dallas the day her husband was assassinated.
A line from Singin’ in the Rain, from the scene in which Lina Lamont is taking elocution lessons.
976 numbers were often used for adult chat lines. They were also used to market to kids, which led to parental complaints; one child racked up a $17K bill, and the FTC cracked down.
The Phantom of the Opera, which most people know either as the stage musical or the film, was originally a serialized French novel by Gaston Leroux, first published in 1909.
Romanian musician Gheorghe Zamfir became part of pop culture when TV ads for his albums began playing seemingly nonstop in the ‘80s.
“Never darken my door again” is a phrase from Victorian melodramas. Better known today, perhaps, is Groucho Marx’s variant from Duck Soup: “Go, and never darken my towels again!”
Pin the tail on the donkey is also a party game dating back to Victorian England. A Japanese variant, Fukuwarai, involves pinning eyes, nose, mouth, etc. on a blank face.
A paraphrase of the opening lines from “(I’ve Had) The Time of My Life,” which was the theme song for Dirty Dancing. It won an Oscar, a Golden Globe, and a Grammy.
This is a standard warning for travelers abroad who wish to avoid “traveler’s diarrhea”; enterotoxigenic E. coli, often found in water, is a common cause.
“How do you handle a hungry man?” was an ad slogan for Campbell’s Manhandlers soups. The jingle was sung by Frankie Laine, who also sang the theme to Blazing Saddles.
“HoJo” is an abbreviation for the Howard Johnson chain of restaurants and hotels, recognizable thanks to their distinctive orange roofs. As of 2016, only one restaurant survives, in New York.
Another name for traveler’s diarrhea, Montezuma’s revenge is named after the last Aztec ruler Moctezuma II (aka Montezuma), who was overthrown by Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés.
A paraphrase of the Australian folk song “Waltzing Matilda,” frequently referred to as that country’s “unofficial national anthem.”
Pirates of the Caribbean was the last Disneyland ride Walt Disney helped design; in 2006 the theme park revamped the ride to incorporate characters from the successful film franchise.
In the closing credits of The Jetsons, George Jetson screams this to his wife when the treadmill he’s using to take his dog Astro for a walk goes awry.
Floyd actor Howard McNear also played Doc Charles Adams on the radio version of Gunsmoke for almost 10 years.
Dr. James Kildare is a fictional character who appeared in print, films, radio, and TV from the ‘30s-‘70s.
The earliest example of a mini golf course dates to 1912. They were popular in the ‘20s, but the Depression finished almost all of them off. A revival began in the ‘50s.
Despite running for 6 years and starring the iconic ‘50s family, Leave It to Beaver never ranked in the Nielsen Top 30 or won any awards.
Billy Barty, who plays the imp in MST3K Episode 806, The Undead, founded Little People of America in 1957 to help foster greater acceptance of little people in society.
Now please enjoy…the fully-annotated Robot vs. the Aztec Mummy!
“The Man of 1,000 Holds” nickname has been used by several pro wrestlers; the first was Earl Caddock. Recently wrestlers Dean Malenko and Chris Jericho have feuded over their right to the title.
Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis were a phenomenally successful comedy team during the ‘50s, starring in a string of movies that included Sailor Beware and Living It Up.
The film Mr. Mom starred Michael Keaton as a father who loses his job while his wife (Teri Garr) gets one, meaning he must become a stay-at-home dad.
The “Fountain of Youth” legend didn’t become attached to Spanish explorer Juan Ponce de León until well after his death.
The Beaver was the nickname given to young Theodore Cleaver (Jerry Mathers) in the TV show Leave It to Beaver.
Learn the truth behind every reference.
This old prank involves putting shoe polish around the eyepieces of binoculars, so when someone uses them, they wind up with large, black circles around their eyes.
Ethel Merman was a booming-voiced actress and singer known for her renditions of “I Got Rhythm,” “Everything’s Coming Up Roses,” and “There’s No Business Like Show Business.”
Beatrice “Bee” Taylor was Andy Taylor’s aunt and caretaker to his son Opie. “Goober” Pyle was Gomer Pyle’s cousin and became the comic relief once Gomer got his own show.
Originally, there were 8 red triple-word-score squares on a Scrabble board; in 2008 Hasbro changed them to orange. Official tournament rules prefer the original boards.
Thanks for watching this fully-annotated presentation of The Robot vs. the Aztec Mummy.
In department stores, the operator of manually controlled elevators would often announce to passengers what products and services were available on each floor.
In McNear’s first episode, Floyd’s last name was Colby; after that, it was established as Lawson.
Did we somehow miss one? Be sure to let us know in the comments!
Speakeasies sold illegal booze during Prohibition; to get in, secret knocks and code words or phrases were used.
On the TV show Bewitched, Dick York played Darrin Stephens, the mortal man hitched to a witch, for the first 5 seasons until an old back injury forced him to leave the show.
13th-century fables tell of animals who see the moon reflected in water and believe it’s a wheel of cheese. References to “green cheese” are not to color but age—a young, white, round cheese.
“Penetrating the mysteries of the great beyond” was not a medal event at the 1920 Summer Olympics, held in Antwerp, Belgium. Tug of war and sculpture were, though.
In real life the Miranda rights are generally read from a card, to ensure the accused cannot get off on a technicality (hence the phrase “read him his rights”).
McNear apparently began having difficulty remembering his lines due to the effects of the stroke and ultimately left the show after season 7.
The Jets are a Minnesota pop group made up of the Wolfgramm family, who, like the Osmonds, are a Mormon household with abundant offspring. Their biggest hit was “Crush on You.”
Elsewhere around the world, the hokey pokey is known as the hokey cokey, okey cokey, hokey tokey, and even the boogie boogie (in the Philippines).
Caesars World was a gaming business in Las Vegas that owned eight casinos and restaurants, including the famous Caesars Palace. It was bought out in 1999.
Eugene Levy played him as a Godfather-type character on SCTV. 30 Rock had a recurring character named Floyd de Barber.
Probably the weirdest attraction ever at Disneyland was in a lingerie shop on Main Street: an animatronic figure that lectured about the history of underwear. It was called the Wizard of Bras.
“Murderlize” or “murdalize” is a bit of tough-talking slang dating to the ‘30s, when it appeared in Three Stooges shorts and was later used by Bugs Bunny in Looney Tunes cartoons.
The theme song for the animated TV show Freakazoid claims that “Floyd the Barber cuts his hair.”
Though some variation of the old watchman’s cry has been around for centuries, the specific phrase “___ o’clock and all’s well” goes back at least to POW camps during the US Civil War.
Ads in the ‘80s for Kellogg’s Frosted Mini-Wheats had adults eating the cereal and appreciating its wholesomeness before transforming into kids and raving about its sugary taste.
The opening credits of Jackie Gleason’s classic sitcom The Honeymooners showed a large animated moon over a city skyline.
Actor Peter Graves has appeared in five films on MST3K, including SST: Death Flight and a voiceover part in Attack of the Eye Creatures.
A sleeper hold is a type of chokehold, most often used in wrestling, that knocks out the opponent. It is extremely dangerous and can even result in death. Do not try it at home.
Buffalo wings were, according to legend, invented by Frank and Teressa Bellissimo at the Anchor Bar in Buffalo, New York, in 1964.
Allstate is an insurance company founded in 1931. Their ad slogan since 1950 has been “You’re in good hands with Allstate.”
There actually is one of these now: the Atomic Trimmer is a nose and ear hair trimmer made to look like a sci-fi ray gun.
In a poorly received 1997 film remake, Beaver was played by Cameron Finley.
A paraphrase of a famous line from the 1980 film The Elephant Man.
According to legend, Hershey’s Kisses got their name from the sound and movement made by the machine that placed the molten chocolate on the conveyor belt during production.
Similarly, the legend that green M&Ms are an aphrodisiac began to spread in the ‘70s.
A paraphrase of a line from the film Airplane!
The round-faced, gap-toothed Willard Scott is best known as The Today Show’s weatherman, but he started out as a clown, playing Bozo in Washington DC and doing ads as the original Ronald McDonald.
An IUD (intrauterine device) is a type of birth control that is placed inside the uterus.
In the Bowery Boys movies of the ‘40s and ‘50s, certain fight moves were called “routines” and assigned numbers.
The original phrase is “fight your way out of a wet paper bag,” and it dates back at least to 1916.
He was replaced by Dick Sargent, who stayed in the role until the show ended.
In the ‘50s TV show Adventures of Superman, Superman enthusiastically leaped from open windows every week to fly to the rescue of Lois and Jimmy.
“(If Loving You Is Wrong) I Don’t Want to Be Right” is an R&B song about an adulterous affair that was a hit in ’72, ’74, and ’78 for three different artists.
Carlos Salazar was an Argentinian boxer in the 1984 Olympics.
This wedding tradition dates back to ancient Rome, and is meant to show that the bride is not unduly eager to lose her virginity.
“I don’t need no stinking badge” is a paraphrase of the Mexican bandit leader’s famous line from the film The Treasure of the Sierra Madre.
Soft-shoe is a variant of tap dancing, usually performed with soft-soled shoes and at a slower pace. It was popular in early 20th-century vaudeville.
In Monty Python’s Life of Brian, the elderly Matthias responds to knocks at the door with a variant on “My legs are grey. My ears are gnarled. My eyes are old and bent.”
Benjamin Sherman “Scatman” Crothers appeared in such films as One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest and The Shining.
An imitation of the narrators of Movietone News, a newsreel that, like serials, played before the main feature film from 1928-63 in the US.
Mr. French was the bearded valet who helped his bachelor employer care for three orphans on the ‘60s TV show Family Affair.
The Michelin Man is white because rubber tires were beige or grey-white before 1912. Modern tires are black because carbon is added to the rubber to strengthen them.
Bob Barker emceed The Price Is Right from 1972-2007. He also hosted Truth or Consequences from 1956-75.
And let us know if we missed any references!
When studios need furniture and other props to break dramatically during a fight scene, they build them out of light, fragile balsa wood.
In the film The Wizard of Oz, Dorothy exclaims this when she first sees the Tin Woodsman.
Betsy Ross is given sole credit for designing and making the American flag in the late 1770s. In reality, she was one of several Philadelphia seamstresses who made flags for the fledgling nation.
A common line in early 20th-century comedies and animated shorts, often spoken by drunkards teetering on the precipice of a curb. It’s a myth that the word “doozy” comes from Duesenberg cars.
Dr. Scholl’s is a foot care brand started in 1906 by podiatrist William Scholl.
Did we somehow miss a reference? Let us know in the comments!
The Copacabana is an NYC nightclub that opened in 1940. It featured performers like Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett, and Sammy Davis Jr. before becoming a disco in the ‘70s.
An imitation of Boris Karloff as Frankenstein’s monster in the 1931 film adaptation of Mary Shelley’s classic novel.
The Oz books do in fact contain lions, tigers, and bears, though only the Cowardly Lion appears in the film. Bru the Bear and the Hungry Tiger (the Cowardly Lion’s BFF) appear in sequels.
Poet/songwriter Rod McKuen was immensely popular during the ‘60s. Frank Sinatra recorded an entire album of his songs and spoken word poetry in 1969.
“Begin the Beguine” is a 1935 song by Cole Porter, made popular by Artie Shaw and his orchestra in 1938; it was one of the classics of the swing era.
A line from the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz.
In the US, the last major Hollywood film released on VHS was A History of Violence in 2006.
Musical chairs (aka “Going to Jerusalem”) is a party game dating back to the 1870s.
Floyd was based on a man named Russell Hiatt who cut Andy Griffith’s hair at the barber shop in his hometown of Mount Airy, NC, on which Mayberry was based.
